A variable-speed drive (VSD) [[air compressor]] <ref>[http://www.quincycompressor.com/qgv.html Variable Speed Drive Compressor]</ref> is an air compressor that takes advantage of [[variable-speed drive]] technology. This type of compressor uses a special drive to control the speed (RPM) of the unit, which in turn saves energy compared to a fixed speed equivalent.
The most common form of VSD technology in the air compressor industry is a [[variable-frequency drive]], which converts the incoming [[Alternating current|AC]] power to [[Direct current|DC]] and then back to a quasi-sinusoidal AC power using an inverter switching circuit. The [[variable-frequency drive]] article provides additional information on electronic speed controls used with various types of AC motors.
==Benefits== The benefits of this technology included reducing power cost, reducing power surges (from starting AC motors), and delivering a more constant pressure. The down side of this technology is the heavy expense associated with the drive, and the sensitivity of these drives ‚Äì specifically to heat and moisture.
==Industry== Typically a fifth of a factory's electricity bill is attributed to the production of compressed air. The majority of modern factories are heavily involved in cutting costs, and energy awareness should be a key concern. For example, 10‚Äì12% of all power generated in the UK is dedicated to the production of compressed air, and a portion of this power is wasted energy.
Large electrical cost savings can be achieved by installing a variable speed drive compressor in place of an existing rotary screw or piston machine. Because of this, many governments, including the US and UK, are pushing the industries to move towards this technology in hopes of reducing wasted energy. Governments offer various incentives, such as tax rebates or interest free loans, to cover the upgrades.
However, variable speed drive compressors are not necessarily appropriate for all industrial applications. If a variable speed drive compressor operates continuously at full speed, the switching losses of the frequency converter result in a lower energy efficiency than an otherwise identically sized fixed speed compressor. Where demand remains constant within 5‚Äì15% of the total free air delivery flow rate, dual-control compressors configured in a split solution can provide higher efficiency than a VFD.
A professional air audit is the best way to identify if a VFD compressor is most appropriate for any given compressed air application.<ref>[http://cascousa.com/our-services/air-system-engineering/ Air Audit]</ref> These audits are available from various companies that specialize in the implementation of compressed air equipment, which can determine the most efficient controls for a compressed air system ‚Äì including variable speed, variable capacity or using storage and flow controllers<ref>[https://www.ace-group.eu/places-might-find-compressor/ Industrial Air Compressor]</ref>.
==See also== * [[Variable-speed drive]] * [[Variable-frequency drive]] (VFD) * [[Rotary screw compressor]] * [[Air compressor]]

{{Infobox company | name = Voxy | logo = Voxy Company Logo.png | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = 2010 | location = [[New York, NY]] | key_people ='''[[Paul Gollash]]''', Founder & CEO

'''Katharine Nielson, PhD.''', Chief Education Officer | industry = [[E-Learning]] | homepage = [http://www.voxy.com www.voxy.com] }} '''Voxy''' is a web-based English [[eLearning]] company providing institutions with an adaptive, dynamic curriculum and personalized instruction.{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2010/09/28/voxy-language-learning-media/|title=Voxy teaches languages through news and text messages|author=Matthew Lynley|publisher=Venture Beat|date=September 28, 2010|accessdate=October 9, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.maswired.com/voxy-music-turns-songs-into-english-lessons/|title=Voxy Music turns songs into English lessons|author=Elaine Rita Mendus|publisher=Maswired|date=September 24, 2012|accessdate=October 9, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2012/07/27/startups-education-online/|title=5 Startups Transforming Online Education|publisher=Mashable|date=July 27, 2012|accessdate=October 14, 2013}} Voxy has three million users in more than 20 countries, and has been rated the #1 education app in 23 countries.{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2013/08/02/voxy-gets-8-5m-for-its-english-language-learning-apps/|title=Voxy gets $8.5M for its English-language learning apps|author=Christina Farr|publisher=Venture Beat|date=August 2, 2013|accessdate=October 9, 2013}} Voxy was founded in February 2010 by Gregg Carey and [[Paul Gollash]]. The company is headquartered in [[NoHo]], [[New York City]], and also has an office in [[S√£o Paulo]], [[Brazil]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=117432068 |title=Company Overview of Voxy, Inc |author= |website=bloomberg.com |publisher=Bloomberg LP |access-date=24 April 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-hottest-10-startups-to-watch-in-nyc-this-year-2012-2 |title=The Hottest 10 Startups To Watch In NYC This Year |last1=Huhman |first1=Heather |date=21 February 2012 |website=businessinsider.com |publisher=Business Insider Inc |access-date=24 April 2015}}{{cite web |url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/voxy |title=Voxy |author= |website=crunchbase.com |publisher=AOL Inc |access-date=27 June 2015}} ==History== Voxy officially launched at TechCrunch Disrupt 2010 in San Francisco. The executive chairman of the Voxy board is Timothy Murray.{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/timothy-murray-joins-voxys-board-of-directors-as-executive-chairman-300273617.html|title=Timothy Murray Joins Voxy's Board of Directors as Executive Chairman|work=PR Newswire|date=May 24, 2016}} PhD linguist Katharine B. Nielson is the chief education officer.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesleadershipforum/2014/05/08/three-surprising-ways-to-use-technology-to-learn-a-language/ |title=Three Surprising Ways to Use Technology to Learn a Language |last1=Nielson |first1=Katharine |date=8 May 2014 |website=forbes.com |publisher=Forbes, Inc |access-date=24 April 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wnyc.org/story/please-explain-how-we-learn-foreign-language/ |title=Some Tips on How To Learn a Foreign Language |last1=Lopate |first1=Leonard |date=27 June 2014 |website=wnyc.org |publisher=New York Public Radio |access-date=24 April 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.icelw.org/program/ICELW%202013%20Proceedings/ICELW2013/papers/Nielson.pdf |title=Online Language Learning in the Workplace: Maximizing Efficiency, Effectiveness, and Timeon-Task |last1=Nielson |first1=Katharine |date=12 June 2013 |website=icelw.org |publisher=The International Conference on E-Learning in the Workplace |access-date=24 April 2015}} In 2014, after receiving increased interest in the Voxy platform from several universities, Voxy expanded its offerings to corporations and educational institutions. Voxy software is used by universities, language institutes, and corporations in countries including Brazil, [[Mexico]], [[Colombia]], [[the United States]], Argentina, Vietnam, Taiwan, Saudi Arabia, Russia, Italy and [[Spain]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wiredacademic.com/2012/07/interview-language-learning-startup-voxy-focusing-on-growth-in-brazil-latin-america/|title=Interview: Language Learning Startup Voxy Focusing On Growth In Brazil, Latin America|author=Paul Gladder|publisher=Wired Academic|date=July 16, 2012|accessdate=May 22, 2015}} In 2013, Voxy partnered with [[Pearson PLC]] to expand to more countries including China.{{cite web |url=http://pando.com/2013/08/02/voxy-is-a-different-english-teacher-for-the-new-global-economy/ |title=Voxy is a different English teacher for the new global economy |last1=Mott |first1=Nathaniel |date=2 August 2013 |website=pando.com |publisher=Pando Daily |access-date=24 April 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://gigaom.com/2013/08/02/language-learning-heats-up-voxy-gets-8-5m-to-help-the-world-learn-english/|title=Language learning heats up: Voxy gets $8.5M to help the world learn English|author=Ki Mae Heussner|publisher=Gigaom|date=August 3, 2013|accessdate=May 22, 2015}} The company developed an online English course for Internet multinational [[Terra Networks]].{{cite web |url=http://noticias.terra.com.br/educacao/terra-lanca-cursos-de-ingles-personalizados-em-parceria-com-a-voxycom,9532f6ac7c125410VgnCLD2000000dc6eb0aRCRD.html |title=Terra lan√ßa cursos de ingl√™s personalizados em parceria com a Voxy.com |author= |date=2 April 2014 |website=Noticias.terra.com.br |access-date=24 April 2015}} Voxy‚Äôs biggest market is Brazil. Prior to the [[2014 World Cup]] in [[Brazil]], Voxy distributed its English language-learning platform to 40,000 affiliates of the [[taxicab|car service]] 99Taxis.{{cite web |url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3030750/most-creative-people/ahead-of-the-world-cup-voxy-rolls-out-english-language-learning-for-bra |title=Ahead of the World Cup, Voxy Rolls Out English Language Learning for Brazilian Cabbies |last1=Zax |first1=David |date=20 May 2014 |website=fastcompany.com |publisher=Mansueto Ventures, LLC |access-date=24 April 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://qz.com/210192/a-language-app-is-getting-brazils-taxi-drivers-in-shape-for-the-world-cup/ |title=A language app is getting Brazil‚Äôs taxi drivers in shape for the World Cup |last1=Feltman |first1=Rachel |date=16 May 2014 |website=qz.com |publisher=Atlantic Media |access-date=24 April 2015}} In 2014, Voxy announced a partnership with Brothers For All, a South African nonprofit dedicated to providing educational support to ex-inmates of the South African prison system and at-risk youth.{{cite web|url=https://d2gcdhp37krz23.cloudfront.net/uploads/PR-Brother-for-all.pdf|title=Voxy Partners With Brothers For All In Helping Ex-Inmates Prepare For Digital World|author=Voxy|date=December 10, 2014|accessdate=March 6, 2015}} Voxy donated free software licenses to the new Brothers For All study center in [[Langa, South Africa]], giving students in an underserved community full access to Voxy‚Äôs platform and credits to enroll in live group classes. In December 2015, Voxy received a patent for its customized keyword extraction process for second language learning.{{citeweb|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/voxy-patents-innovative-approach-to-second-language-learning-300196480.html|title=Voxy Patents Innovative Approach to Second Language Learning|publisher=PR Newswire|date=22 December 2015|access-date=25 January 2016}} ==Product== Voxy is built on the principles of [[task-based language learning]], and tailors every single course based on learners‚Äô daily performance, proficiency levels, personal goals, and interests.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/shamahyder/2014/09/08/15-tech-companies-taking-nyc-by-storm/ |title=15 Tech Companies Taking NYC By Storm |last1=Hyder |first1=Shama |date=8 September 2014 |website=forbes.com |publisher=Forbes Inc |access-date=24 April 2015}} The Voxy curriculum uses authentic content that is relevant to learners, including up-to-date news articles from leading publishers, English songs, videos of people accomplishing daily tasks, and audio recordings of real-life situations. Voxy delivers a fully integrated web and mobile platform that syncs across all of a user‚Äôs devices.{{cite web|url=http://www.maswired.com/mobile-app-voxy-helps-latinos-learn-english/|title=Mobile app Voxy helps Latinos learn English|publisher=Maswired|date=August 1, 2012|accessdate=October 14, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://smallbusiness.foxbusiness.com/entrepreneurs/2012/01/05/startups-aim-to-bring-education-industry-into-21st-century/ |title=Startups Aim to Bring Education Industry Into 21st Century |publisher=Fox Business|date=January 5, 2012|accessdate=October 14, 2013}} The platform includes live in-product instruction through one-on-one tutoring sessions and group classes with certified teachers who provide real-time feedback.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mariela-dabbah/immigrants-must-learn-eng_b_1107647.html|title=Immigrants Must Learn English Fast|publisher=Huffington Post|date=November 23, 2011|accessdate=October 14, 2013}} Voxy also offers advanced reporting, dashboard visualization, and performance analytics to keep track of how learners are doing. To assess proficiency level at the beginning of the program, Voxy uses its own proprietary test, the Voxy Proficiency Assessment‚Ñ¢ (VPA‚Ñ¢). Learners can retake the VPA‚Ñ¢ every three months to measure their improvement, and courses will automatically adapt to updated proficiency levels. Voxy has pioneered numerous innovations in [[contextual learning]], including the use of [[natural language processing]] tools and [[geo-location]]. ==Funding== In its [[Series A]] round, Voxy received $4.1 million in funding from investors including Weld North, New York City Investment Fund (NYCIF), Seavest Inc., Contour Venture Partners, and ff Venture Capital. Voxy received $2.3 million in funding from return investors including [[ff Venture Capital]], Contour Venture Partners, and Seavest Capital Partners in a [[Series B|Series A-2]] round in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://betabeat.com/2012/03/voxy-raises-4-million-ff-venture-capital-contour-venture-partners-seavest-language-learning-app-03262012/|title=Language Learning Startup Voxy Raises a $4 M. Round from ff Venture Capital, Contour, and Seavest|publisher=Beta Beat|date=March 26, 2012|accessdate=May 22, 2015}} In 2013, Voxy received $8.5 million from Pearson in a [[Series B]] with participation from Rethink Education. Voxy raised a $12 million funding found in March 2017, which was dedicated to the expansion of its e-learning app. The funding round was led by SFJ Ventures.{{cite web| url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/03/30/voxy-raises-12-million-to-roll-out-its-e-learning-english-app-in-emerging-markets/| publisher=Venture Beat| title=Voxy raises $12 million to roll out its e-learning English app in emerging markets| access-date=April 25, 2017| author=Berenice Magistretti| date=March 30, 2017}} ==Awards and recognition== [[Business Insider]] named Voxy one of the 10 best U.S. technology companies to work for in 2012,{{cite web|url=http://articles.businessinsider.com/2012-03-17/news/31195914_1_employees-vote-la-mode-aaron-levie|title=The 10 Best US Tech Companies To Work For In 2012|author=Heather R. Huhman|publisher=Business Insider|date=March 17, 2012|accessdate=October 9, 2013}} and Internet Week New York named Voxy one of the top 30 places to work in the New York City tech industry in 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.internetweekny.com/media/press_releases/52|title=Internet Week Unveils Its First-Ever List Of 30 Best Places To Work In New York City Tech Industry|author=Jenny Chang, Mark McArthur|publisher=Internet Week|date=October 17, 2014|accessdate=March 6, 2015}} In 2015, Voxy was recognized as an Academics' Choice Award Winner for "Smart Media."{{cite web| url=http://www.academicschoice.com/websites/voxy.php| title=Voxy| publisher=Academics' Choice| access-date=August 26, 2015}} ==See also== * [[Distance learning]] * [[E-Learning]] * [[Language education]] * [[English as a second language]] * [[Second language acquisition]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://voxy.com Voxy.com] - Official website [[Category:Language education]] [[Category:Companies established in 2010]] [[Category:Companies based in New York City]]

{{Coord|41|32|10|N|81|34|6.5|W|type:landmark_region:US-OH|display=title}} {{Infobox Observatory |name = Warner and Swasey Observatory |image = [[Image:Warner and Swasey 9.5inch refracting telescope.jpg|200px]] |caption = The rooftop telescope with the dome open |organization = [[Case Western Reserve University]] |location = [[Cleveland, Ohio]] (USA) |coords = {{Coord|41|32|10|N|81|34|6.5|W|type:landmark_region:US-OH|display=inline}} |altitude = |weather = |established = |closed = |website= |telescope1_name = Burrell Schmidt Telescope |telescope1_type = 24" Schmidt |telescope2_name = Rooftop Telescope |telescope2_type = 9.5" refractor}}
The '''Warner and Swasey Observatory''' is the astronomical [[observatory]] of [[Case Western Reserve University]]. Named after [[Worcester R. Warner]] and [[Ambrose Swasey]], who built it at the beginning of the 20th century, it was initially located on Taylor Road in [[East Cleveland, Ohio|East Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], USA. The observatory, which at that time housed a {{convert|9.5|in|cm|adj=on}} [[refracting telescope|refractor]], was donated in 1919 to the Case School of Applied Science. The newer {{convert|24|in|cm|adj=on}} Burrell [[Schmidt telescope]] was built in 1939.
Due to rising [[light pollution]] in [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], a new station in [[Geauga County, Ohio|Geauga County]]'s [[Montville Township, Geauga County, Ohio|Montville Township]] was established in 1950s. Named after [[Jason John Nassau]], the station initially housed the Burrell telescope, which was later moved to [[Kitt Peak National Observatory]]. Instead of Burrell the station was equipped with the 36-inch robotic telescope. In 2008 Nassau Station was sold to the [[Geauga Park District]] and subsequently incorporated into its Observatory Park.
The observatory currently operates the old 9.5-inch refractor (now known as the rooftop telescope) at the university's [[University Circle]] campus, and the Burrell Schmidt telescope at [[Kitt Peak National Observatory]] in [[Arizona]]. The old site on Taylor Road was sold in 1983.
==History== [[Image:Warner and Swasey Observatory.jpg|thumb|upright|The Taylor Road facility of the Warner and Swasey Observatory]]
The observatory was originally built by Worchester R. Warner and Ambrose Swasey, owners of [[Warner & Swasey Company]], which made precision instruments and [[telescope]]s in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. They became trustees of the Case School of Applied Science (later renamed to [[Case Institute of Technology]]), and built an observatory in [[East Cleveland, Ohio|East Cleveland]], which they gave to the school in 1919. This original observatory building was located on Taylor Road four miles east of the university campus and housed a 9.5-inch [[refracting telescope|refractor]], and was dedicated in 1920. The building was designed by the firm of [[Walker and Weeks]].<ref>{{cite book |title=A Cleveland Legacy: The Architecture of Walker and Weeks |last=Johannesen |first=Eric |date=1998 |publisher=Kent State University Press |location=Kent, Ohio |isbn=0-87338-589-6 |pages=87‚Äì88 |url=http://upress.kent.edu/books/Johannesen.htm}}</ref> In subsequent years the observatory grew to house several more telescopes and instruments, such as the 24-inch Burrell Schmidt telescope, as well as an astronomical library and public lecture hall.<ref name=History>{{cite web|last=Claspy|first=William|publisher=Warner and Swasey Observatory, Case Western Reserve University|title=History of the Warner and Swasey Observatory|url=http://astrwww.cwru.edu/history.shtml|date=2006|accessdate=2009-08-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509072403/http://astrwww.cwru.edu/history.shtml|archivedate=2008-05-09|df=}}</ref>
In the 1950s, it became apparent that the [[light pollution]] from Cleveland was beginning to make cutting-edge research impossible from the East Cleveland site. A new site was constructed 30 miles to the east in [[Geauga County, Ohio|Geauga County]], known today as the Nassau Station, and the Burrell Schmidt telescope was moved to this location. In order to compensate for the move, a 36-inch telescope was soon installed at the Taylor Road facility.<ref name=History/>
In 1978, the Astronomy Department of [[Case Western Reserve University]] made a deal with the [[Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy]] (AURA) to build a new observatory at [[Kitt Peak National Observatory]] to house the Burrell Schmidt. The telescope was moved from [[Ohio]] to [[Arizona]] in May 1979, and in 1980 the 36-inch [[reflecting telescope|reflector]] on Taylor Road was moved to the Nassau Station. This meant no further astronomical work was done at the Taylor Road facility, and as a result the faculty and resources of the original observatory were moved to the main campus of Case Western Reserve University in 1982.<ref name=History/> The Taylor Road facility was sold in 1983, was abandoned, and remained neglected until 2005 when it was sold to a couple who planned to convert the building into a [[House|residence]].<ref name=flipline>{{cite web|title=The History....|url=http://www.flipline.com/wso/history.html|accessdate=2009-08-18|publisher=The Warner & Swasey Observatory Restoration project|last=Elek|first=Tim|last2=Neff|first2=Matt|last3=Solary|first3=Tony|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704065403/http://flipline.com/wso/history.html|archivedate=2008-07-04|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=O'Malley |title=Family's New Focus: Turning Old Observatory Into Home |url=http://www.cleveland.com/whateverhappened/plaindealer/index.ssf?/whateverhappened/more/observatory.html |work=[[The Plain Dealer]] |location=Cleveland, Ohio |date=2005-09-07 |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607163203/http://www.cleveland.com/whateverhappened/plaindealer/index.ssf?%2Fwhateverhappened%2Fmore%2Fobservatory.html |archivedate=2011-06-07 |df= }}</ref> The plans stalled when its new owner was convicted of [[mortgage fraud]] and sent to prison in 2007.<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=O'Malley |title=Nayyir Al Mahdi's dream of turning observatory into home ended with indictment |url=http://www.cleveland.com/whateverhappened/plaindealer/index.ssf?/whateverhappened/more/nayyir.html |work=[[The Plain Dealer]] |location=Cleveland, Ohio |date=2008-01-28 |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607163303/http://www.cleveland.com/whateverhappened/plaindealer/index.ssf?%2Fwhateverhappened%2Fmore%2Fnayyir.html |archivedate=2011-06-07 |df= }}</ref>
==Telescopes== [[Image:The Warner & Swasey Observatory at Kitt Peak National Observatory.jpg|thumb|The Warner and Swasey Observatory at [[Kitt Peak National Observatory]]]]
===Burrell Schmidt Telescope=== The 24-inch Burrell Schmidt Telescope was originally built in 1939 by [[Warner & Swasey Company]] of [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] and was housed at the Taylor Road facility.<ref name=Nassau>{{cite journal|last=Nassau|first=J.J.|title=The Burrell telescope of the Warner and Swasey Observatory|date=1945|journal=Astrophysical Journal|volume=101|pages=275‚Äì279|doi=10.1086/144719|bibcode=1945ApJ...101..275N}}</ref> It is currently housed at [[Kitt Peak National Observatory]] near [[Tucson, Arizona]]. The telescope recently had its optics upgraded with a very wide field of view [[CCD array]], which is much more sensitive than the [[photographic plate]]s. It is the instrument used today by the Case astronomers.<ref name=NewsLetter>{{cite journal|title=New Camera Sees "First Light" on Burrell Schmidt Telescope|url=http://astroweb.case.edu/news/Newsletter092008.pdf|format=pdf|date=September 2008|journal=Astronomy Department Newsletter|publisher=Case Western Reserve University|page=1}}</ref>
===Nassau Station Robotic Observatory=== The Nassau Station, originally constructed in the 1950s, currently houses a 36-inch reflecting telescope. It is named after observatory director [[Jason John Nassau]], who was a prominent astronomer at the time.<ref name=Griffith>{{cite web|first=S.|last=Griffith|date=1997|title=Observatory Upgrades Planned as 40th Anniversary arrives|url=http://www.cwru.edu/pubs/cnews/1997/10-2/observ40.htm?nw_view=1250781578&|accessdate=2009-08-20|publisher=Case Western Reserve University}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Work was carried out in the 1990s to make the telescope capable of remote viewing, making it one of the first telescopes to be used in this manner.<ref name=Sciencedaily>{{cite news|title=CWRU's Nassau Telescope Goes Online In December For Public Use|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/1998/12/981203075623.htm|accessdate=2009-08-20|date=3 December 1998|work=ScienceDaily}}</ref> However, it was seldom used by Case astronomers due to increased light pollution from Cleveland and the enhanced capabilities of the Burrell Schmidt. As a result, the observatory was left unused for several years until 2008, when it was sold to the [[Geauga Park District]].<ref>{{cite press release |title=Geauga Park District purchases Nassau Observatory from Case Western Reserve University |url=http://blog.case.edu/case-news/2008/10/09/nassauobservatory |publisher=[[Case Western Reserve University]] |date=2008-10-09 |accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref> The park district reopened the facility as part of its Observatory Park on June 16, 2012.<ref>{{cite news |first=Joan |last=Rusek |title=Geauga's Observatory Park Opens Early for Historic View of Venus |url=http://www.cleveland.com/west-geauga/index.ssf/2012/06/post_43.html |work=[[Sun Newspapers|Sun News]] |date=2012-06-21 |accessdate=2012-11-26 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Elizabeth |last=Lundblad |title=Geauga Park District's Observatory Park Helps Visitors See the Stars |url=http://www.news-herald.com/articles/2012/11/25/news/nh6261754.txt |work=[[The News-Herald (Ohio)|The News-Herald]] |date=2012-11-25 |accessdate=2012-11-26 }}</ref> The park was designated as a dark sky park by the [[International Dark Sky Association]].<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Mangels |title=$2 million Geauga park would preserve a patch of dark sky |url=http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2009/02/2_million_geauga_park_would_pr.html |work=[[The Plain Dealer]] |location=Cleveland, Ohio |date=2009-02-24 |accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref>
===Rooftop Telescope=== The Rooftop Telescope is a 9.5-inch refractor that was originally constructed in 1894 by Warner and Swasey for their own use.<ref name=flipline/> The telescope was the first instrument of the Warner and Swasey Observatory and was originally used at the Taylor Road facility, but was put into storage when the Astronomy Department of Case Western Reserve University was relocated to the A. W. Smith building on the main campus. In 1986 the telescope was reinstalled in a new dome on the roof of the A. W. Smith building.<ref name=Cuyahoga>{{cite web|title=Ohio's Observatories: CWRU Observatories|url=http://www.cuyastro.org/ohioobs.html|accessdate=2009-08-18|publisher=Cuyahoga Astronomical Association|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913064335/http://www.cuyastro.org/ohioobs.html|archivedate=2009-09-13|df=}}</ref>
The telescope remains in excellent condition today and is available for use by all students, faculty, and staff at CWRU once they go through a seminar on proper telescope use.<ref name=Cuyahoga/> It is also often used for public observing nights by the university's Physics and Astronomy Club.
==Research== [[Image:Burrell Schmidt telescope at the Warner & Swasey Observatory at Kitt Peak.jpg|thumb|upright|The Burrell Schmidt telescope at the Warner and Swasey Observatory at Kitt Peak National Observatory]]
Observers using the Warner and Swasey Observatory have made important contributions to astronomical research. An early example is work carried out by the observatory's then director, Jason Nassau, on the classification of [[carbon star]]s and [[stellar classification|M-type stars]] in 1949;<ref name=Blanco>{{cite journal|last=Blanco|first=Victor M.|journal=Annual Review of Astronomy and Astrophysics|volume=39|issue=1|pages=1‚Äì18|date=September 2001|url=http://arjournals.annualreviews.org/doi/full/10.1146/annurev.astro.39.1.1?cookieSet=1#h4|doi=10.1146/annurev.astro.39.1.1|title=Telescopes, red stars, and Chilean skies|bibcode=2001ARA&A..39....1B}}</ref> more recently, observations made using the Burrell Schmidt telescope led to the discovery of the galaxy [[Andromeda VIII]] in 2003. This galaxy orbits the more famous [[Andromeda Galaxy]], and was previously undiscovered due to its position in front of the bright disk of the parent galaxy.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Morrison|first=H.L.|author2=Harding, P. |author3=Hurley-Keller, D. |author4= Jacoby, G. |date=2003|title=Andromeda VIII: A New Tidally Distorted Satellite of M31|journal=Astrophysical Journal|volume=596|issue=2|pages=L183‚ÄìL186|bibcode=2003ApJ...596L.183M|doi= 10.1086/379625|arxiv = astro-ph/0309254 }} ([http://www.noao.edu/outreach/press/pr03/cwru0301.html Observatory press release])</ref> The Burrell Schmidt has also recently been used to image the intracluster light in the [[Virgo Supercluster]]. The intracluster light is a thousand times fainter than the night sky, and was observed after combining seventy images of the cluster which were taken with the Burrell Schmidt telescope.<ref name=Virgo>{{cite web|last=Mihos|first=C.|display-authors=etal |date=2005|title=Diffuse Light in the Virgo Supercluster|url=http://astroweb.case.edu/hos/Virgo/|accessdate=2009-08-18}}</ref>

Thorsett]]{{cite news|last=Much|first=Justin|title=New Willamette U. president returns to deep roots in Salem|url=http://www.statesmanjournal.com/article/20110514/UPDATE/110514003/New-Willamette-U-president-returns-deep-roots-Salem?odyssey=tab%7ctopnews%7ctext%7cHome|accessdate=May 14, 2011|newspaper=Statesman Journal|date=May 14, 2011}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} |head_label = Chairman of the Board of Trustees |head = Dale C. {{convert|80|acre|m2}} |former_names = [[Oregon Institute]]
Wallamet University |free_label = |free = |sports = 20 Varsity Teams |colors = Cardinal & Old Gold{{Color box|#C41E3A|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|#CFB53B|border=darkgray}} |nickname = [[Willamette Bearcats|Bearcats]] |mascot = Blitz |athletics = [[NCAA Division III]]
[[Northwest Conference]] |affiliations = [[Annapolis Group]] |website = [http://www.willamette.edu Willamette.edu] |logo = [[File:WillametteUlogo.png|260px]] |footnotes = }} '''Willamette University''' is a [[private university|private]] [[liberal arts colleges in the United States|liberal arts college]] in [[Salem, Oregon]]. Founded in 1842, it is the oldest university in the [[Western United States]].{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/geo/www/us_regdiv.pdf |title=As defined by the US Census Bureau |format=PDF |accessdate=February 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120131930/http://www.census.gov/geo/www/us_regdiv.pdf |archivedate=January 20, 2013 |df=mdy }} Willamette is a member of the [[Annapolis Group]] of colleges, and is made up of an undergraduate College of Liberal Arts and post-graduate schools of business and law. The university is a member of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]'s Division III [[Northwest Conference]] and was featured in [[Loren Pope]]'s ''[[Colleges That Change Lives]]''. Willamette's mascot is the [[binturong|bearcat]] and old gold and cardinal are the school colors. Approximately 2,800 students are enrolled at Willamette between the graduate and undergraduate programs. The school employs over 200 full-time professors on the {{convert|69|acre|m2|adj=on}} campus located across the street from the [[Oregon State Capitol]]. Originally named the [[Oregon Institute]], the school was an unaffiliated outgrowth of the [[Methodist Mission]]. The name was changed to Wallamet University in 1852, followed by the current spelling in 1870. Willamette founded the first medical school and law school in the [[Pacific Northwest]] in the second half of the 19th century. In the 20th century, the school started a [[sister school]] relationship with [[Tokyo International University]] and began competing in intercollegiate athletics. Willamette's undergraduate programs exist within the school's College of Liberal Arts. The school was rated 82nd among American liberal arts colleges by ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' for 2018.{{cite web |title=National Liberal Arts Colleges - Willamette University |publisher=''U.S. News & World Report'' |url=https://www.usnews.com/best-colleges/willamette-3227/overall-rankings |accessdate=November 3, 2017}} The oldest of the graduate programs is the [[Willamette University College of Law|College of Law]], founded in 1883 and currently located in the Truman Wesley Collins Legal Center. Established in 1974, [[Atkinson Graduate School of Management]] is housed in the Seeley G. Mudd Building. The [[Willamette University School of Education|School of Education]], established in 1996, had an enrollment of 100 students,{{cite web|url=http://www.willamette.edu/dept/ir/factbooks/by_year/2012-2013/fall/enrollment.htm |title=Fall 2012 University Enrollment Headcount & FTE |publisher=Willamette.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-11-15}} but closed in 2014.{{cite news|title=Willamette Faculty Upset That Graduate School Of Education Will Close|url=http://www.opb.org/news/article/willamette-university-profs-upset-that-graduate-school-of-education-will-close/|accessdate=11 September 2013|publisher=Oregon Public Broadcasting|date=August 5, 2013}} ==History== The university was founded as the [[Oregon Institute]] by the missionary [[Jason Lee (missionary)|Jason Lee]], who had arrived in what was then known as the [[Oregon Country]] in 1834 and had founded the Indian Manual Labor Institute for the education of the local [[Native Americans of the United States|Native Americans]]. Lee requested additional support for his mission, and received 53 additional volunteers in 1839, who arrived on the ship ''[[Lausanne (ship)|Lausanne]]''. After a series of meetings in Lee's home, the by-laws were adopted and board of trustees elected and the institute was officially established on February 1, 1842. The Oregon Institute officially opened on August 13, 1844 with a total of five students and one teacher, Mrs. [[Chloe Clark Willson|Chloe Clarke Willson]].{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/about/history/highlights_1834-1899.html|title=About: History of Willamette: 1834 - 1899 {{!}} Willamette University|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}} Lee served as the first President of the Board of Trustees, followed by [[David Leslie (Oregon politician)|David Leslie]] after Lee's death in 1845. Leslie would serve until his death in 1869.Gatke, Robert Moulton. 1943. ''Chronicles of Willamette, the pioneer university of the West''. Portland, Or: Binfords & Mort. The original purpose of the institute was the education of the missionaries' children. [[File:Eaton Hall from OSC.JPG|left|thumb|[[Eaton Hall (Oregon)|Eaton Hall]] built in 1909]] The original building of the institute was a three-story frame structure first occupied in 1844. At the time, it was one of the largest structures in the [[Pacific Northwest]]. It housed the first session of the state legislature to meet in [[Salem, Oregon|Salem]] after the capital was moved there in 1851. The building burned down in 1877. In 1867, a new brick building was finished to house the school and named University Hall. The building was renamed as [[Waller Hall]] in 1912 to honor the Reverend [[Alvin F. Waller]], and is now the oldest university building west of the [[Mississippi River]] still in use. The first president was [[Francis S. Hoyt]], who served in that position from 1853 until 1860 and was replaced by [[Thomas Milton Gatch]] who is the only president of the school to serve as president two different times.[http://www.willamette.edu/about/president/past/index.html Past Presidents.] Willamette University. Retrieved on September 13, 2007. The name of the institution was changed to "Wallamet University" in 1852. The following year, the [[Oregon Territorial Legislature]] granted a charter to the university. The first graduate was Emily J. York, who received a degree as Mistress of English Literature in 1859.{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/about/history/highlights_1834-1899.html|title=About: History of Willamette: 1834 - 1899 {{!}} Willamette University|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}} In 1866, the university established the first [[Willamette University School of Medicine|school of medicine]] in the [[Pacific Northwest]].Cowan, Ron. Willamette University's first archivist puts a face on history. ''[[Statesman Journal]]'', September 19, 2007. The current spelling of the university was adopted in 1870. In 1883, the university established the first [[Willamette University College of Law|law school]] in the Pacific Northwest during the presidency of [[Thomas Van Scoy]].[http://www.willamette.edu/history.htm About Willamette: History of Willamette.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101103065742/http://www.willamette.edu/history.htm |date=November 3, 2010 }} Willamette University. Retrieved on December 5, 2007. The school of medicine then merged with the [[University of Oregon]] in 1913 and is now [[Oregon Health and Science University]].Horner, John B. (1919). ''Oregon: Her History, Her Great Men, Her Literature''. The J.K. Gill Co.: Portland. p. 246-7. In December 1941, the university's football team traveled to Hawaii to play the [[University of Hawaii]]. Many students accompanied the team by passenger ship to [[Oahu]]. The game was played was on December 6. The following day, many of the Willamette students witnessed the bombing of [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|Pearl Harbor]] from their hotels on [[Waikiki|Waikiki Beach]]. Their return trip was delayed by many weeks, and some of the students returned to Oregon by helping on ships transporting the wounded to the mainland.{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/about/history/highlights_1900-1949.html|title=About: History of Willamette: 1900 - 1949 {{!}} Willamette University|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}} Many of the team members stayed with football players from [[Punahou School]]. During World War II, Willamette was one of 131 colleges and universities nationally that took part in the [[V-12 Navy College Training Program]] which offered students a path to a Navy commission.{{cite web |url=http://www.palynology.org/history/tschudy.html |title=AASP Primary Records Program |publisher=U.S. Geological Survey |last=Nichols |first=D.J. |accessdate=September 29, 2011 |year=1987 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907095050/http://www.palynology.org/history/tschudy.html |archivedate=September 7, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} [[Lausanne Hall]], previously a women's residence, served as a "ship" for trainees between 1943 and 1945.{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/about/history/highlights_1900-1949.html|title=About: History of Willamette: 1900 - 1949 {{!}} Willamette University|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}} In 1965, Willamette and the [[Tokyo International University]] entered a sister-college relationship. The Tokyo International University in America, on Willamette University's campus, was completed in 1989.{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/about/history/highlights_1950-1999.html|title=About: History of Willamette: 1950 - 1999 {{!}} Willamette University|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}} [[Liz Heaston|Elizabeth Heaston]], of the class of 1999, became the first female to play in a collegiate football game in 1997.{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/about/history/highlights_1950-1999.html|title=About: History of Willamette: 1950 - 1999 {{!}} Willamette University|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}} In 2013, the Willamette community broke the world record for largest game of [[Statues (game)|Red Light/Green Light]] with 1,060 players, and reclaimed the record in August, 2015, with 1,203 players.{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/about/history/highlights_2010-present.html|title=About: History of Willamette: 2010 - Present {{!}} Willamette University|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}} ==Campus== [[File:Waller Hall nw corner.JPG|thumb|[[Waller Hall]], completed in 1867 is the oldest building on campus.]] [[File:WillametteULausanneHall.jpg|thumb|[[Lausanne Hall]]]] The {{convert|69|acre|adj=on}} campus is directly south of the [[Oregon State Capitol]], affording students access to internships in the institutions of [[Government of Oregon|Oregon government]]. Much of downtown Salem, including the Capitol, is on land once owned by the university. Railroad tracks are located directly east of the school, with the [[Salem (Amtrak station)|Salem Amtrak Station]] near the southeastern edge of campus. South of the school is [[Salem Hospital (Oregon)|Salem Hospital]], with [[Bush's Pasture Park]] and the school's [[McCulloch Stadium]] opposite the hospital. Willamette's core area lies between State Street on the north, Bellevue Street on the south, Winter Street to the west, and 12th Street on the east. On the west side of Winter Street lie the university's graduate programs in business and law.{{cite web|url=http://www.willamette.edu/map/campus_map.pdf|title=Willamette University Campus Map|date=December 1, 2008|publisher=Willamette University|accessdate=June 20, 2009}} Additional school properties outside of the core area are the [[Hallie Ford Museum of Art]], the [[Oregon Civic Justice Center]], the Tokyo International University of America campus, and several residential buildings. Willamette owns several other properties along State Street west of the main campus. The school plans on redeveloping portions of the west end of campus in order to better tie the campus to downtown Salem.{{cite news|title=Plan blurs boundaries of Willamette U, Salem|last=Cowan|first=Ron|date=January 8, 2006|work=Statesman Journal|page=1A}} Academic buildings on campus include [[Eaton Hall (Oregon)|Eaton Hall]] and Smullin/Walton Hall, which are primarily used by humanities departments. Science classes are generally held in the Collins and Olin buildings. Willamette's music program is housed by the G. Herbert Smith Auditorium and Fine Arts building, as well as the Mary Stuart Rogers auditorium. Administrative offices are found in the Putnam University Center and [[Waller Hall]], Willamette's oldest building. Waller Hall was built using bricks made of clay from the campus quad. Willamette's newest buildings, including the Goudy Commons, Kaneko Commons (a [[residential college]] opened in the Fall of 2006),{{cite web | title =Kaneko Commons ‚Äì Willamette University | work =Willamette University web site | date =July 21, 2006 | url =http://www.willamette.edu/dept/campuslife/res_commons/kaneko/ | accessdate =April 5, 2007 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070212073941/http://www.willamette.edu/dept/campuslife/res_commons/kaneko/ | archivedate =February 12, 2007 | df =mdy-all }} and Rogers Music Center have all been designed by the Zimmer Gunsul Frasca Architects. Ford Hall, near [[Gatke Hall]] on State Street, is a new academic building completed in the Fall of 2009. In addition to Greek housing, eleven residence halls exist on the Willamette campus. Undergraduate students are under contract to live on campus for two years, after which they may move into private residence or one of the university's apartment complexes. [[Lausanne Hall]], originally home of the university's Women's College, is now one of the university's undergraduate dormitories. The building commemorates the ship that brought the reinforcements to Lee in 1839. York Hall commemorates the university's first graduate. [[File:WillametteUniversityStream.jpg|thumb|left|The Mill Stream runs through campus past the Mark O. Hatfield Library and Jackson Plaza.{{Cite news|url=https://map.concept3d.com/?id=895#!ct/17758,17894|title=Willamette University Interactive Map|access-date=2018-06-29|language=en}}]] The Mill Stream runs through the middle of the campus. Starting across 12th Street and flowing through the length of the campus, it passes by the [[Martha Springer Botanical Garden]], the [[Mark O. Hatfield Library|Hatfield Library]], Hudson Hall, the University Center, Smith Auditorium and Goudy Commons. This artificial stream, commonly referred to as the Mill Stream, was once known as the Mill Race. It forms a "W" shape when viewed from the University Center. Biology and environmental science classes utilize the Mill Stream as an authentic research venue. As part of the freshman matriculation ceremony, new students place a lit candle into the Mill Stream and watch it float downstream. On-campus athletics facilities are located in the southeast portion of the campus. These include a soccer field, tennis courts, and the Sparks Center. Softball, football, and baseball stadiums are located outside of the main campus. {{Panorama|image=Image:Willamette_University.jpg |fullwidth=9927 |fullheight=1525 |caption=The grounds of Willamette University. Visible are the Mark O. Hatfield Library, the clock tower, and the Mill Stream that runs through the campus. |height=240}} ==Academics== {{Infobox US university ranking | ARWU_W = | ARWU_N = | THES_W = | USNWR_LA = 82 | Wamo_LA = 53 | Forbes = 140 }} ===College of Liberal Arts=== The mission of the College of Liberal Arts (CLA) is to "maintain a setting which encourages and sustains students and faculty in the practices of liberal education."{{cite web |url=http://willamette.edu/cla/catalog/overview/cla/mission/index.php |title= College of Liberal Arts: Mission and Goals |accessdate=July 30, 2009 |last=Hedlund |first=Rose |date=17 July 2009 |work=2009‚Äì2010 CLA Catalog |publisher=Willamette University |pages= Academic Interview }} The undergraduate program is able to be personal with a student-faculty ratio of 10:1.{{cite web|url=http://www.willamette.edu/dept/ir/cds/by_year/2012/instructional_faculty_and_class_size.htm |title=I. Instructional Faculty and Class Size |publisher=Willamette.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-11-15}} Students conduct original research, publish papers and are able to design their own academic paths. ===Admissions=== For the class of 2020 (enrolling fall 2016), Willamette received 6,350 applications and enrolled 430.{{cite web |url=http://willamette.edu/offices/ir/cds/by_year/2016/index.html |title=Willamette University Common Data Set 2016, Part C |publisher=Willamette University |accessdate=September 27, 2017}} For the freshmen who enrolled, the middle 50% range of [[SAT]] was 1180-1390, while the [[ACT (examination)|ACT]] composite range was 27‚Äì30. Of the 57% of enrolled freshmen who submitted high school class rank, 40% were in the top 10% of their high school classes and 73% ranked in the top quarter. The average high school GPA for incoming freshmen was 3.79. For the 2014-2015 academic year, tuition, housing, and fee charges were $58,817.{{cite web |url=http://willamette.edu/offices/ir/cds/by_year/2015/index.html |title=Willamette University Common Data Set 2015, Part G |publisher=Willamette University |accessdate=November 15, 2016}} Willamette awarded about $30.2 million in need-based aid to its students that year, with the average financial aid package equal to $35,204.{{cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/offices/ir/cds/by_year/2015/index.html |title=Willamette University Common Data Set 2015, Part H |publisher=Willamette University |accessdate=November 15, 2016}} In terms of merit-based aid, the majority of Willamette scholarships and grants are awarded to students with demonstrated financial need.{{cite web |url=http://www.willamette.edu/dept/finaid/current/index.html |title=Financial Aid: Financial Aid For Current Undergraduate Students | Willamette University |publisher=Willamette.edu |accessdate=February 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201124912/http://www.willamette.edu/dept/finaid/current/index.html |archivedate=February 1, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} Willamette University is a [[Common Application]]-exclusive school, and is test-optional.{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/cla/admission/apply/first_year/index.html|title=Admission: Apply: First-Year {{!}} Willamette University|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}} All students who apply for admission are automatically considered for merit-based scholarships, which range from $5,000 to $25,000 per year. The university accepts the [[FAFSA]] to determine financial aid packages.{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/offices/finaid/undergraduate-students/scholarships/willamette-scholarships/index.html|title=Willamette Scholarships, Financial Aid {{!}} Willamette University|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}} ===Programs and resources=== The CLA offers 35 majors, six minors and seven special programs, including pre-law, pre-med and a BA/MBA program.{{cite web |url=http://willamette.edu/cla/catalog/overview/cla/graduation/index.php |title=Graduation Requirements |accessdate=July 28, 2009 |last=Hedlund |first=Rose |date=17 July 2009 |work=2009‚Äì2010 CLA Catalog |publisher=Willamette University }}{{cite web |url=http://www.willamette.edu/cla/catalog/overview/opportunities/healthcare/index.php |title= Healthcare |accessdate=July 28, 2009 |last=Hedlund |first=Rose |date=17 July 2009 |work=2009‚Äì2010 CLA Catalog |publisher=Willamette University |pages= Career, Graduate and Professional Opportunities }}{{cite web |url=http://willamette.edu/academics/pdfs/ba_mba_combined.pdf |title=BA/MBA Combined Degree |accessdate=July 28, 2009 |author=Office of Admissions |format=Brochure PDF |publisher=Willamette University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100530064109/http://www.willamette.edu/academics/pdfs/ba_mba_combined.pdf |archivedate=May 30, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} The most popular areas of study are biology, politics, psychology, economics, civic communication and media, and English,{{cite web|url=http://www.willamette.edu/dept/ir/factbooks/by_year/2011-2012/spring/undergraduate_enrollment_by_major.htm |title=Spring 2012 Undergraduate Enrollment by Major |publisher=Willamette.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-11-15}} and learning takes place both in and outside of the classroom. For example, students earn credit as political interns at the [[Oregon State Capitol]], across the street from campus; study the effects of climate change at the nearby research forest; or conduct epidemiology surveys for the local health department.{{cite book |author1=M. Lee Pelton |author2=Ronald Korvas |author3=Nadene LeCheminant |author4=Sarah Evans | year=2008 |title=Four E‚Äôs of Sustainability: Annual Report of the President, Willamette University 2008 |publisher=Willamette University}} Students in service-learning courses base papers and projects on their community service experience,{{cite web |url=http://willamette.edu/cla/catalog/resources/campuslife/index.php |title=Campus Life |accessdate=July 29, 2009 |last=Hedlund |first=Rose |date=17 July 2009 |work=2009‚Äì2010 CLA Catalog |publisher=Willamette University |pages=Campus Resources |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907020122/http://www.willamette.edu/cla/catalog/resources/campuslife/index.php |archive-date=September 7, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} and more than half of Willamette's undergraduate students study abroad, choosing from programs in 40 countries.{{cite web |url=http://willamette.edu/cla/catalog/overview/programs/abroad/index.php |title=Study Abroad |accessdate=July 29, 2009 |last=Hedlund |first=Rose |date=17 July 2009 |work=2009‚Äì2010 CLA Catalog |publisher=Willamette University |pages= Programs of Special Interest }} Co-located with [[Tokyo International University|Tokyo International University of America]], Willamette offers opportunities for students interested in Japanese language and culture, and connections to Asia and the Pacific Rim.{{cite web |url=http://www.collegenews.org/x6699.xml |title=Japanese Flourishes Mark Dedication of Willamette's Kaneko Commons |accessdate=July 29, 2009 |last=Evans |first=Sarah |date=19 July 2007 |work=College Campus News |publisher=Annapolis Group}} Carson Grants offer undergraduates the opportunity to undertake a scholarly, creative or professional research project during the summer,{{cite web |url= http://willamette.edu/cla/catalog/overview/programs/carson/index.php|title=Carson Undergraduate Research Grant |accessdate=July 29, 2009 |last=Hedlund |first=Rose |date=17 July 2009 |work=2009‚Äì2010 CLA Catalog |publisher=Willamette University |pages=Programs of Special Interest }} and the [[Lilly Endowment|Lilly]] Project provides grants, internships and programs to help students discern their "calling in life" and create meaningful professional paths.{{cite web |url= http://willamette.edu/cla/catalog/overview/programs/lilly/index.php |title=Lilly Project |accessdate=July 29, 2009 |last=Hedlund |first=Rose |date=17 July 2009 |work=2009‚Äì2010 CLA Catalog |publisher=Willamette University |pages=Programs of Special Interest }} Sustainability mini-grants also provide students with opportunities to initiate contributions to campus sustainability efforts. Five academic Centers of Excellence provide opportunities for student-faculty collaboration and research.{{cite web |url= http://willamette.edu/cla/catalog/overview/programs/centers/index.php |title=Academic Centers |accessdate=July 29, 2009 |last=Hedlund |first=Rose |date=17 July 2009 |work=2009‚Äì2010 CLA Catalog |publisher=Willamette University |pages=Programs of Special Interest }} Eleven faculty members have been named Oregon Professor of the Year by the [[Council for Advancement and Support of Education]] (CASE) since 1990.{{cite web|url=http://www.willamette.edu/about/recognition/professor_of_the_year/|title=About: Recognition: Oregon Professors of the Year - Willamette University|work=willamette.edu}} The U.S. Professors of the Year program recognizes educators who demonstrate an extraordinary dedication to undergraduate teaching through, "impact on and involvement with undergraduate students; scholarly approach to teaching and learning; contribution to undergraduate education in the institution, community and profession; and support from colleagues and current and former undergraduate students."{{cite web |url=http://www.usprofessorsoftheyear.org/POY_Display.cfm?&contentItemID=6389&pid=PR_Resources |title=U.S. Professors of the Year Fact Sheet |accessdate=July 30, 2009 |publisher=Counsel for Advancement and Support of Education }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The 2008 [[Princeton Review]] described Willamette as "academically rigorous, intimate and seriously gorgeous,"{{cite web | last = Kelly | first = Brian | title = Princeton Review's 366 Best Colleges | publisher = Princeton Review | url = http://blog.willamette.edu/news/pdfs/2007/princeton_review.pdf | accessdate = July 7, 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5s7VeR0aN?url=http://blog.willamette.edu/news/pdfs/2007/princeton_review.pdf | archivedate = August 20, 2010 | df = mdy-all }} and the school ranked fifth in [[Seattle Metropolitan]]'s Northwest college rankings. The magazine cited the school's alumni roster, wireless features, "outdoorsy aesthetic" and new residence hall.{{cite news | last = Halverson | first = Matthew | author2 = Durham, Stefan | title = Northwest College Rankings 2008 | work = Seattle Metropolitan | place = Seattle | publisher = Saga City Media, Inc. | date = October 2008 | url = http://www.seattlemet.com/arts-and-entertainment/category/family/articles/1008-feat-collegerankings/2/ | accessdate = July 1, 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110721050621/http://www.seattlemet.com/arts-and-entertainment/category/family/articles/1008-feat-collegerankings/2/ | archivedate = July 21, 2011 | df = mdy-all }} ===Graduate programs=== {{main|Willamette University College of Law|Atkinson Graduate School of Management|Willamette University School of Education}} Located on the western side of the campus are the university's two graduate level schools. The College of Law is the oldest and largest of the programs, with the Atkinson Graduate School of Management being smaller and newer. The College of Education at Willamette closed in 2014.{{cite web|title=Willamette University plans to end graduate teaching program|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/education/index.ssf/2013/06/willamette_university_plans_to.html|website=Oregon Live|publisher=Oregon Live|accessdate=29 September 2016}} Atkinson and the College of Law offer a joint-degree program that allows students to earn both an [[MBA]] and [[juris doctorate]]. ==Campus life== [[File:Willamette Jackson Plaza.JPG|thumb|Jackson Plaza outside the library]] The university's weekly newspaper, the ''[[Willamette Collegian]]'', began publishing in 1875. The school has over 100 student organizations ranging from sport clubs, political groups, and social clubs to religious groups and honor societies.[http://www.willamette.edu/dept/osa/orgs/list/?category=All List of Student Organizations.] Willamette University. Retrieved on November 26, 2007. Willamette University has many active clubs and intramural sports on its campus, including rugby, poi spinning, ultimate frisbee, basketball, and others.{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/offices/osa/orgs/list/index.html|title=Student Activities: Student Organization List|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-09}} The Outdoor Program organizes around 120 trips each year, and more than half of students participate in trips like kayaking, camping, skiing, hiking, whale-watching, and more.{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/news/library/2016/03/outdoor-program.html|title=The student-run program gives students an affordable means to build connections with their peers while exploring Oregon's natural wonders.|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}} ===Greek life=== There are five fraternities and three sororities at Willamette. The sororities are [[Pi Beta Phi]], [[Alpha Chi Omega]], and [[Alpha Phi]]. Alpha Chi Omega and Pi Beta Phi have their own houses located along sorority row on Mill Street. The fraternities at Willamette are [[Phi Delta Theta]], [[Kappa Sigma]], [[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]], [[Beta Theta Pi]], and [[Sigma Chi]].{{Cite web|url=http://willamette.edu/offices/osa/greek/index.html|title=Student Activities: Fraternity & Sorority Life|website=willamette.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-09}} Greek life at Willamette began in the 1920s with the foundation of several local fraternities and sororities. In 1942, G. Herbert Smith, a member of [[Beta Theta Pi]], became President of Willamette, and invited national fraternities and sororities onto campus. The local fraternities were soon converted into national fraternities and sororities. Pi Beta Phi became the first national sorority at Willamette in 1944, and Beta Theta Pi, Sigma Chi, and Phi Delta Theta were installed in 1947. At its peak, there were six fraternities and five sororities at Willamette. Two other sororities, [[Chi Omega]] and [[Alpha Phi]], and the fraternity [[Delta Tau Delta]], used to have chapters at Willamette. In the mid-1990s, Delta Tau Delta lost its charter. The two sororities lost their charters after their move to sorority row. Chi Omega was transformed into a multicultural oriented residence known as WISH (Willamette International Studies House). In the spring of 2014, Alpha Phi accepted an invitation from the university's Panhellenic Council to reorganize their chapter on Willamette's campus. In the fall of 2014, Beta Theta Pi began recolonization of its chapter on Willamette's campus with the consent of the university's Inter-Fraternity council. ==Athletics== {{main|Willamette Bearcats}} [[File:McCullochStadium.JPG|thumb|McCulloch Stadium]] The [[Willamette Bearcats|Willamette University Bearcats]] compete at the [[NCAA Division III]] level. Willamette fields teams in baseball, basketball, cross-country, golf, football, soccer, softball, swimming, tennis, track & field, lacrosse and volleyball.{{Cite web|url=http://wubearcats.com/landing/index|title=Willamette University|website=Willamette University|language=en|access-date=2018-06-29}} In 2021, Willamette will begin the first women's varsity triathlon program in the Pacific Northwest and the 23rd program nationally.{{Cite news|url=https://www.statesmanjournal.com/story/sports/2018/05/09/willamette-university-first-northwest-add-womens-triathlon/590684002/|title=Willamette University to be first in Northwest with women's triathlon program|work=Statesman Journal|access-date=2018-06-29|language=en}} Willamette is a founding member of the [[Northwest Conference]] league. The football team plays home games at [[McCulloch Stadium]] south of the main campus, while basketball, swimming, and volleyball teams use the Lestle J. Sparks Center for home events. At or adjacent to McCulloch are the [[Charles J. Bowles|Charles Bowles]] Track used for track meets and [[Spec Keene|Roy S. "Spec" Keene]] Stadium where baseball plays its home games.[http://www.willamette.edu/athletics/facilities/ Athletics: Facilities.] Willamette University. Retrieved on November 26, 2007. will be the first university in the Pacific In 1991, the university started the Willamette University Athletic Hall of Fame. In 1993, the school earned its only team sport national championship when the men's basketball team earned the NAIA Division 2 title.{{cite web|url=http://www.salemhistory.net/education/willamette_university.htm|title=Willamette University|last=Gibby|first=Susan|year=2000|work=Salem Online History|publisher=Salem Public Library|accessdate=June 20, 2009}} '''Notable Willamette Athletes''' As an undergraduate, Olympian Nick Symmonds won the 800 NCAA championship race all four years and the 1,500 NCAA championship race as a freshman, junior, and senior.{{cite web|url=http://www.usatf.org/athletes/bios/Symmonds_Nick.asp |title=Nick Symmonds |publisher=USATF |date=December 30, 1983 |accessdate=February 2, 2012}} Symmonds later went on to place fifth in the 800 meter run at the 2012 Olympic Games. In 2007, Sarah Zerzan won the NCAA Division III title in cross country.[http://www.willamette.edu/athletics/teams/cross_country/results/2007/Nov%2B17%2B-%2BNCAA%2BNational%2BChampionships%2B-%2BWomen.txt NCAA Division III Cross Country Championships ‚Äì Women]{{dead link|date=February 2012}} In 1997, [[Liz Heaston]] became the first woman to ever play in a college football game when the Bearcats beat rival [[Linfield College]]. She kicked two extra points in the game. Also that year, the football team finished its best season losing in the NAIA National Championship game to the University of Findlay 14‚Äì7.Gilman, Andrew. "Willamette falls short in bid for NAIA title", ''The Oregonian'', December 21, 1997, p. C1. In 2014, [[Conner Mertens]] became the first active college football player to come out publicly about his sexuality. Mertens generated international headlines when he publicly addressed being bisexual.{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxsports.com/college-football/story/report-division-iii-kicker-conner-mertens-tells-coaches-i-m-bisexual-012814|title='I'm bisexual': Kicker becomes first CFB player to come out publicly|date=2014-01-28|work=FOX Sports|access-date=2018-06-29|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.outsports.com/2014/1/28/5348936/conner-mertens-willamette-football-kicker|title=College football player Conner Mertens comes out|work=Outsports|access-date=2018-06-29}} On Dec. 7, 1941, Willamette's football team was in Honolulu, Hawaii, for the Shrine Bowl when Japanese forces attacked Pearl Harbor. Team members and fans who had made the trip volunteered for 10 days following the attack as guards at Punahou School and nurses at the U.S. Navy hospital. The 1941 team, known today on Willamette's campus as "the Pearl Harbor Football Team," was inducted into the Willamette University Athletic Hall of Fame in 1997.{{Cite news|url=http://www.wubearcats.com/sports/fball/2011-12/releases/08_FB_Pearl_Harbor_Game.html|title=Bearcats to Honor Willamette's Pearl Harbor Football Team from 1941|date=2011-11-08|work=Willamette University|access-date=2018-06-29|language=en}} ==Notable faculty== *[[Charles J.
